title: Solar Eclipse 2017: What is it and how to watch February's total eclipse of the sun
text:
A total solar eclipse is seen from the beach on Ternate island, Indonesia, March 9, 2016 (Photo: REUTERS/Beawiharta) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Today the moon will pass in front of the sun, creating a solar eclipse visible in the southern hemisphere. 
The eclipse will leave a halo of light surrounding the sun, as normal sunlight is blocked out. 
Unfortunately, we won't be able to see it here in the UK - it will only be visible in parts of South America and Africa. 
Of course, last time we had an eclipse in the UK, pesky cloud cover obscured the dramatic view for millions of people. Where will you be able to see the eclipse? 
The eclipse will begin in Chile and pass over Argentina's Patagonia region before being visible across the South Atlantic Ocean and eventually in Angola. It will end near the border of Zambia and the Democratic Republic of Congo at sunset. 
This is the first of two solar eclipses happening in 2017. The second will occur over the USA on August 21. Read More An aeroplane flies past the sun as it goes into a partial solar eclipse in Singapore March 9, 2016 (Photo: Reuters) Why does a solar eclipse happen? 
Solar eclipses are due to the moon's orbital tilt which causes it to pass between the Earth and the Sun. 
However, they occur very rarely because the moon orbits at an angle of 5 degrees off the Earth's own orbital plane around the sun, and spins on an axis that is actually tilted towards our own planet. When will the eclipse take place? A partial solar eclipse is seen through clouds in Bangkok, Thailand, March 9, 2016 (Photo: Reuters) Read More Comet flyby LIVE: Watch as this bizarre green comet passes through our solar system tonight 
This month's solar eclipse will begin at 12:10 UTC, reach its maximum point at 14:58 UTC and set at 17:35 UTC. 
Of course, up here in the far reaches of the northern hemisphere, we won't be able to witness the event. 
The last solar eclipse to be visible in this country took place in 2015. When is the next Solar Eclipse in the UK? 
We won't see another eclipse over these shores until June 10 2021. 
Then a partial eclipse will take place across Britain ranging from 50% in northern Scotland to 30% in south-east England. Read More
